rename.from: Error when trying to Jooin predict results with DataFrame
rename.to: Error when trying to Join predict results with DataFrame

body: @MarijnQ can you please provide an example of the contents of both dft and predictions? The issue may be related with the lack of unique index.

> 

Hiya, Sure I can.
dft is a csv with 3 columns called "Query"(text) "URL Clicks"(int) and "Impressions"(int)
predictions is defined as a tuple value when I research it in python. but it seems like all the data is locked up in 1 cell and I cant extract it.

Can you post here the prints of those two dataframes? (the first few lines)
If there's sensible data, you redact it. It's just for understanding better the contents of both of them.

> 

Aha, yes sure.
so dft is like this
Query,Url Clicks,Impressions
what is a wet signature,320,41835
signing for someone else with permission uk,118,1026
is an electronic signature legal uk,87,735
what should your signature be,77,1153

and predictions is:
(      Category0_predictions  ... Category0_probabilities_ABBREVIATION
 0               DESCRIPTION  ...                             0.011631
 1               DESCRIPTION  ...                             0.021409
 2                    ENTITY  ...                             0.125703
 3                    ENTITY  ...                             0.119312
 4                    ENTITY  ...                             0.068843
 ...                     ...  ...                                  ...
 11196           DESCRIPTION  ...                             0.011269
 11197                 HUMAN  ...                             0.034313
 11198           DESCRIPTION  ...                             0.019942
 11199                ENTITY  ...                             0.119312
 11200                ENTITY  ...                             0.005736
 
 [11201 rows x 10 columns], 'results')

@MarijnQ And both DFs have the same number of rows, and what you are trying to obtain is a signle df with the the union of the columns of both right?
In that case, I believe you may want to cancatenate them
```
pd.concat([dft, predictions.reindex(dft.index)], axis=1)
```
as explained here: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/merging.html (cell 12)

@MarijnQ I'm not sure i understand what you mean by "When I take a look at the predictions file, I get the 10 columns and the 11k rows. however, all the info seemed to be clustered in cell A1 and the rest is empty"

Can you actually paste the contents of predictions (first 6 rows) in a code block here?

> @w4nderlust Thanks for the quick response. I just ran the code again and got the following error `AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'reindex'`
> 
> When I take a look at the predictions file, I get the 10 columns and the 11k rows. however, all the info seemed to be clustered in cell A1 and the rest is empty. Would this be the issue?

Hi @MarijnQ, I'm here to help you solve the issue you are dealing with.  I think what is happening here is that the model.predict function returns a tuple object containing the predictions and an output directory. When the predictions variable is assigned to this tuple object, if you call .reindex, you will get the error you saw above. The way to get this to work is to assign the predictions variable like this `predictions, _ = model.predict(dft.rename(columns={'Query': 'Questions'} ))`. This will assign a pandas DataFrame to the predictions variable which you can then call .reindex() on while concatenating the predictions and training df. If you try `pd.concat([dft, predictions.reindex(dft.index)], axis=1)` after assigning predictions in the manner mentioned above, you should be able to combine the predictions and training DataFrame. Let me know if this works for you!
@connor-mccorm that's a good call, silly of me not realizing it :)
@connor-mccorm I could kiss you! This was the fix I was looking for!
